title: Alfie Allen looks dapper alongside Thomasin Harcourt McKenzie at the Jojo Rabbit premiere in London
text:
They star in the upcoming anti-hate satire movie.

And, Alfie Allen, 33, joined Thomasin McKenzie, 19, on the red carpet at the European Premiere of Jojo Rabbit during the 63rd BFI London Film Festival at Odeon Luxe Leicester Square on Saturday night.

The Game Of Thrones actor looked dapper in a plum coloured suit, which he teamed with a checked shirt, while Thomasin put on a stylish display in a metallic checked trouser suit and silver bejewelled heels.

The stars are out! Alfie Allen, 33, joined Thomasin McKenzie, 19, at the European Premiere of Jojo Rabbit at Odeon Luxe Leicester Square on Saturday night

Speaking on the red carpet, Thomasin explained how she landed the female lead, saying: 'I did an audition, my first ever audition in LA so I was pretty nervous about it. Then I Skyped with Taika and now here we are.

Discussing the diversity of roles and the importance of the story, she added: 'I'm always really keen to tell important stories and share important messages and tell stories that need to be told.'

Roman Griffin Davis, 12, who plays male lead Jojo, discussed working with Scarlett Johansson in the film.

He said: 'She's great, she was encouraging and she's a mother now. She was also a child actress so she knew how it felt to be new and a bit nervous.

Looking good: The Game Of Thrones actor looked dapper in a plum coloured suit

Gorgeous: Thomasin put on a stylish display in a metallic checked trouser suit and silver bejewelled heels

Suave: Alfie looked suave in his smart attire, with a checked grey shirt adding an unexpected twist to his ensemble

She encouraged me, and she was funny and creative. We were having such a fun time on set. It was fun, really fun'.

Sam Haygarth who plays Hans in the film spoke about the difficulty of getting the tone right, admitting: 'I think the interesting thing about this film is that it's dealing with such huge issues and a politically really volatile atmosphere whilst also trying to do that through a comic lens.

'And that's something that, as an actor, but also everybody on set has to be aware of all of the time.

'It's like what is your duty as a storyteller, how are you telling these stories? For us, this was weighing very heavily on our minds.

'A for me as an actor, why I was involved in the film was just to come in, pull a couple of funny faces, be a bit evil and then get on with your life. So there is an extent to which you just come in and do the job as well.

Star-studded line-up: Discussing film, she added: 'I'm always really keen to tell important stories and share important messages and tell stories that need to be told'

Edith Bowman turned heads on the red carpet, stepping out in an oversized brown and red checked trouser suit.

The presenter added a splash of vibrant colour to her ensemble with a bright green pussybow blouse.

Bringing extra pizzazz to her look, Edith donned a metallic pair of gold ankle boots and accessorised with hexagon earrings.

Glam: Edith Bowman turned heads on the red carpet, stepping out in an oversized brown and red checked trouser suit

Here come the boys: Taiki Waititi (left) portrays an idiotic version of Adolf Hitler in the film, while Carthew Neal (right) produced Jojo Rabbit

Jojo Rabbit tells the story of lonely German boy Jojo 'Rabbit' Betzler (Roman Griffin Davis) during World War II,

His worldview gets turned upside down when he discovers his single mother (Scarlett Johansson) is hiding a young Jewish girl (Thomasin McKenzie) in their attic.

The only person he feels he can trust and count on is his imaginary friend, an idiotic version of Adolf Hitler (Taiki Waititi).

Named by Variety as one of the world's 10 Producers to watch, Carthew Neal produced Jojo Rabbit.

Jojo Rabbit hits theatres in the US on October 18.
